column1: The name of the town comes from the Evenk word for "grayling".
It was founded due to the development of the nearby coal basin and was granted town status in 1975.
Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Neryungri serves as the administrative center of Neryungrinsky District. As an inhabited locality
column3: Neryungri is classified as a town under republic jurisdiction. As an administrative division
column4: it is incorporated within Neryungrinsky District as the Town of Neryungri. As a municipal division
column5: the Town of Neryungri is incorporated within Neryungrinsky Municipal District as Neryungri Urban Settlement.

column1: The town is the center of a large coal field discovered about 1970. It is located on the Amur–Yakutsk Mainline and the Lena Highway
column2: 202 kilometers (126 mi) by rail north of Tynda. Nearby
column4: are Berkakit: 10 kilometers (6.2 mi) south; Serebryany Bor: 8 kilometers (5.0 mi) east with a thermal coal power plant; Chulman: 30 kilometers (19 mi) north
column5: with the Chulman Airport; and a large open pit coal mine northwest across the Chulman River.

column1: Neryungri has a subarctic climate ( Köppen climate classification Dfc) with mild summers and severe winters. Precipitation is moderate
column2: but is significantly higher in the summer than at other times of the year. The climate is extremely cold for the latitude in part due to the Siberian High bringing extremely cold polar air to the city in winters
column3: whereas the high elevation usually prevents the heat waves seen in the lower areas of Sakha.
